lines.text: Elizabeth, do we like to dance?
One final matter, under the heading of new business, gentlemen. Or perhaps I should say old business renewed.
What are you up to?
I'm packing, I'm going with you.
Absolutely not.
But I'm in just as much danger here as I would be in London. By now they've got to realize that I know who you are!
I don't care. You are not going with me; that's final.
[Next scene finds them on the plane together]
in spite of what you think, I'm your friend.
I believe you Ralph, I believe you. But you chose a heartwarming way of expressing it tonight.
I've decided I don't like Tony Sutton - or his friends. Is that all he did? Go to parties and play polo?
Well, he didn't have to do anything else, he was rich.

A rich playboy... polo, skiing in St. Maritz, cruising the Mediterranean with the jet set. What a life! A whole world coming apart at the seams, and all Tony Sutton can do is bounce about like a rubber ball.
And then you would fall into fits of depression that lasted days, sometimes weeks... always inside yourself. And you drank. Richard, you tried to drink yourself to death.
Why did you marry me?
I loved you. You needed help, and I thought I could give it to you. I loved you. How do you think I feel, when you say I'm part of a plot? I know nothing about it.
But you wanted a divorce. Why?
I couldn't go on being only a nurse to you.
Richard, I've had two vices - poetry and gambling. Poetry enriches the soul, gambling depletes the bank account.
Sir Howard Nettleton. Chairman of the Board of Governors of our school, citizen of conscience, and swindler in the gold markets.
*Manipulator*.
Good morning.
Good morning.
It's a nice car.
I'll never be able to afford one as a school master. Will you marry me?
But we are married.
No, you're married to Tony Sutton.
I'd like very much to marry you.
We'll fix that.

And you were in my dream, Ralph. You were helping these people. Every time I had doubts, every time my new identity began to slip, you were there to reassure me. Isn't that odd? Then, all of a sudden, I was on a polo field, falling from a horse. And in that one instant, I realized...
Mmn - yes, you must forgive me, I hadn't realized it was so late.

[Richard and Elizabeth are dancing]
You seem different.
Different better, or different worse?
Different better - Tony would never have held me this close.

[draws away from her]
I'm sorry, I am Tony Sutton. I must play the part; we are being watched.
You just allowed yourself the luxury of trusting me, didn't you?
You know me better than I do.
If you wouldn't mind coming along with me, sir, I have to draw up a full report.
And you file it under UFO sightings.
I was never really cut out to be a private investigator, you know, sir. House of Commons is more to my taste.
What is it?
Sir, there's an inspector Huntington from Scotland Yard, waiting for you in your study.
Ahha, Scotland Yard, that's very interesting, thank you Brandon.
Sir?
Yes?
Are you guilty, or not guilty?
Guilty, of course. I chopped her up in little pieces and mailed them.
My coat of arms, Mr. Stuart, if I had one, would bear the motto "rapid service", inscribed on a field of blue.
Well, I'm sorry to have disturbed you, Mr. Banes, but we have to look into these reports - however wild and irresponsible they may be.
Thank you sergeant.
I'm afraid you've been burgled, sir.
Burgled? Robbed?
Much the same thing.
I assume they paid you well?
Well handsomely, old chap. Luckiest day in my life when you asked me to check on that license number. Which reminds me - I owe you a tenner.
Suppose you first show me precisely where all this took place.
Just you alone?
I represent the law, sir.
Richard, I'm afraid.
Yes.
You afraid?
Yes.
Are they going to kill us?
No.
Do you know why Big Ben is called Big Ben, Mr. Stuart?
No, but I have a feeling I'm going to.

Big Ben was named for Sir Benjamin Hall, commissioner of works during the time it was built in 1859, during the reign of Queen Victoria. It stands three hundred and twenty nine feet tall, and contains a bell weighing thirteen tonne. You didn't hear a word I said, sir.
Oh, a few of them.
What is this about a club?
Across the lake. There's a garden party tonight.
I think we should go.
Under these circumstances?
Why not? I think it's time to see how my other half lived.
What is this key for?
Dr. Sawyer said that is belonged to your father, and if you ever asked for an explanation, he'd give it to you.
And Tony never did, of course?
No.
That key, Elizabeth, was a calculated risk. A constant challenge to my memory - or lack of memory. The bait, you see. As long as I didn't inquire about it, my past was *locked.*

[reading for the poetry club]
In secret we met / In silence I grieve / That thy heart could forget, / Thy spirit deceive.

[interrupts and finishes]
If I should meet thee / After long years, / How should I greet thee? / With silence - and tears.
Ralph, all these years you've been a secret romantic, and you've never told me. But then of course we never really knew each other. Did we?
